DOC.HEAD: Spy Plane's 25th Anniversary Being Marked in Flight
DOC.TEXT: A spy plane that was one of the mainstays of Cold War intelligence-gathering today was marking its 25th anniversary with a flight over its maker's once-secret plants. The SR-71 Blackbird was to take off from Air Force Plant 42 in Palmdale and fly over Lockheed Corp.'s plants in Burbank and Rye Canyon. An SR-71 first flew on Dec. 22, 1964. Since then, Blackbirds, which can fly at least three times the speed of sound and higher than 85,000 feet, have helped U.S. intelligence keep watch on sensitive areas around the globe. President Bush last week signed a defense appropriation bill that did not include funding for the SR-71. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney and other top Pentagon officials had advocated dropping the program. The Blackbird _ angular, with short wings and enormous engines _ replaced the U-2, a high-flying but slow craft.
